input:
PSV 2 - 1 Manchester

First Half:

0:0 Comment: Watches are synchronised around Europe and away we go.
0:3 Comment: Manchester United back in the Champions League.
0:7 Comment: Here come PSV,
0:8 Comment: Treurper playing it forward to Luke de Jong.
0:11 Comment: Didn't make much impact during his time at Newcastle.
0:15 Comment: But he's among the goals here this season,
0:17 Comment: five in the first five league games.
0:19 Comment: CHEERING
0:27 Comment: Great surface, big noise here in the southern part of Holland,
0:32 Comment: about 90 minutes on the train from Amsterdam.
0:37 Comment: Daley-Blik to get it away.
0:39 Comment: WHISTLE BLOWS
0:46 Comment: Easily cut out by Burnett, the left-back.
0:51 Comment: Louis van Gaal there, return home for him,
0:53 Comment: he swept everything in front of him when he was here with Ajax
0:57 Comment: and won the title with AZ Altmaier as well.
0:59 Comment: But he never got much joy coming to this stadium,
1:3 Comment: only a couple of wins in 11 visits.
1:9 Comment: Said yesterday, this is a tough place to play,
1:14 Comment: they don't make many mistakes at home,
1:16 Comment: PSV Eindhoven, but it is a young side they've got here.
1:20 Comment: Yeah, it's young, it's inexperienced,
1:22 Comment: Manchester United have got a couple of young inexperienced players as well,
1:26 Comment: but also added to that with the likes of Schweinsteiger in midfield.
1:31 Comment: Experiencing some of the more important players, I think that's more key.
1:36 Comment: Milner in experience, out wide or up front is all right,
1:39 Comment: but holding midfield players, defenders,
1:42 Comment: I think experience is key in these type of games.
1:45 Comment: It's a bit of a heavy touch there by Adera in midfield,
1:49 Comment: nearly let Lester Yeun in, but Chris Smalling,
1:51 Comment: who's been in fabulous form so far this season, broke all that up.
1:54 Comment: And the captains are banned tonight.
1:59 Comment: Young, towards Martial.
2:7 Comment: Loose ball from the youngster,
2:10 Comment: and then commits the foul right afterwards as well.
2:13 Comment: And the referee wants a word as early as the third minute.
2:20 Comment: Yeah, it wasn't such a bad foul from Martial,
2:23 Comment: I think the danger in it was he was pushing him in to Schweinsteiger,
2:27 Comment: which could have been a little bit dangerous, but losing the ball there,
2:30 Comment: not so important in that type of area, you've got to try things in the opponent's third.
2:35 Comment: I think that's what you're gonna get from Martial.
2:37 Comment: He's gonna be quite raw, gonna make mistakes,
2:40 Comment: and can also turn the game on its head like we saw at the weekend.
2:44 Comment: There was all that hype about him maybe one day being a new Thierry Henry,
2:50 Comment: that's not putting any pressure on a youngster, is it?
2:52 Comment: But I tell you what, that goal he scored was a bit reminiscent of Henry.
2:55 Comment: Yeah, and he's got a similar profile, hasn't he, obviously coming from France.
2:59 Comment: And he wasn't so prolific, was he, at his previous club,
3:3 Comment: but nor was Thierry Henry when he came,
3:5 Comment: and he developed into one of the Premier League's finest,
3:8 Comment: so that's what everybody's hoping for Martial, let's see if he can deliver.
3:13 Comment: 15 goals in 70 games it was for Monaco, to answer your question, Michael.
3:19 Comment: Brenet.
3:21 Comment: Nice turn by Propa.
3:23 Comment: Good idea, he's a good young player coming through one of the new signings in the summer.
3:29 Comment: Here's the man who is the heartbeat of the team, Guardado, the Mexican international.
3:37 Comment: Good player and has been for a long time.
3:41 Comment: Here's the former Chelsea man, Jeffrey Bruma.
3:46 Comment: Nice!
3:55 Comment: This fella Propa is interesting, they signed him from Vitesse Arnhem,
3:59 Comment: he's a good passer of the ball and can make things happen,
4:2 Comment: they've got quite good hopes of him.
4:5 Comment: He's kind of taken Wijnaldum's place in these parts.
4:9 Comment: And here's Young, very good cameo in the second half at the weekend from him.
4:14 Comment: He's regained his place in the starting line-up.
4:18 Comment: First time he's been in since the opening game.
4:21 Comment: Yeah, some would say quite unfortunate to lose his place,
4:24 Comment: Ashley Young, he had a really good start to the season.
4:28 Comment: Made a difference as well when he came on at the weekend against Liverpool.
4:31 Comment: Here's Moreno, another experienced Mexican international,
4:43 Comment: his second appearance for the club after his signing in the summer.
4:47 Comment: Now then, here's Memphis, he's got a warm reception from the fans,
4:51 Comment: they still love him around here despite the fact he left.
4:54 Comment: He could have left a year earlier.
4:57 Comment: He stayed and helped them win the title by a huge margin last season.
5:4 Comment: He's played up towards de Jong, he's crowded out by Chris Smalling.
5:16 Comment: And here's Daly Blint, his first goal at Old Trafford at the weekend,
5:21 Comment: and what a strike it was against Liverpool.
5:27 Comment: He's under a bit of pressure in the Netherlands,
5:30 Comment: he's the national team boss,
5:32 Comment: and we're in grave danger of not making it to the European Championship finals next summer.
5:48 Comment: Brunette, wonderheader, Lestien inside.
5:53 Comment: Couldn't control it, now then, Juan Mata playing in his favoured No. 10 role,
5:57 Comment: and he's picked a Pitu Abbas here to Memphis,
6:0 Comment: who couldn't quite bring it under control.
6:2 Comment: And maybe he's been forced a little wider than he would have wanted,
6:5 Comment: and here's a chance for Herrera, who couldn't quite get a touch on it.
6:11 Comment: Well, great break for Manchester United.
6:14 Comment: If Memphis could have just got a touch on that, he would have been through one-on-one,
6:17 Comment: as it was.
6:20 Comment: Nice little run across the front post from Martial,
6:23 Comment: if he had not touched it then I'm sure Herrera could have been in there.
6:26 Comment: But a simple tap-in, a good break, good intent,
6:29 Comment: looked dangerous, Manchester United.
6:38 Comment: Hendricks, only 20, deputising for Andy Mayer in the midfield at the moment.
6:44 Comment: Backing away well.
6:47 Comment: FULL-TIME WHISTLE
6:52 Comment: We mentioned all those famous names who played for PSV Eindhoven in the past,
6:56 Comment: there's a little bit of a worry among some of the local journalists here
7:0 Comment: that the standard of the Dutch league is dropping, maybe a little alarmingly,
7:5 Comment: and we'll see how PSV Eindhoven get on.
7:8 Comment: Ajax didn't make it through to the group stage.
7:12 Comment: Well, it must be so much more tempting than it's ever been, mustn't it,
7:15 Comment: to sell a player nowadays with the money in the English Premier League,
7:18 Comment: not to mention other places.
7:20 Comment: If anyone gets a rough diamond in their ranks,
7:24 Comment: then they can get a big, big premium on them.
7:33 Comment: It was interesting at the press conference last night, Michael Louis van Gaal was asked,
7:37 Comment: would you be happy with a draw?
7:39 Comment: He said, in a way, draw is always good in the Champions League,
7:42 Comment: but he's very mindful it's the first game in the group, we want to start well,
7:46 Comment: we're trying for the win.
7:48 Comment: And there was something kind of similar too from his opposite number, Philippe Coccu,
7:54 Comment: he said, we want to win but we're not going to be naive.
8:6 Comment: Down the end, Champions League debut.
8:9 Comment: Lovely touch, wasn't it, by Martial, the pass not quite so clever.
8:18 Comment: Bruma, towards Guardado, they put the pressure on him,
8:22 Comment: but the foul has been given.
8:26 Comment: Yeah, close one, Herrera certainly nicked the ball,
8:29 Comment: it's just whether he came through the back in the first place,
8:31 Comment: but it was worth taking a chance, I feel, when the ball's being played
8:34 Comment: in and around that area of the pitch,
8:36 Comment: then might as well take a risk of giving away a foul,
8:39 Comment: because if you do win it, the referee doesn't give a foul,
8:41 Comment: then you're in, you're breaking onto the back four.
8:44 Comment: Played towards de Jong but too long.
8:57 Comment: I wonder if that's part of the Manchester United plan tonight,
9:0 Comment: they know everything likes to go through Guardado with PSV,
9:4 Comment: whether they're going to try and high-press him every time the ball's played.
9:10 Comment: Yeah, interested to see early on in the game,
9:12 Comment: Luke Shaw was playing quite high, pressing quite high as well,
9:15 Comment: so I think it's always a good thing to do,
9:18 Comment: if you can win the ball high, obviously less space,
9:22 Comment: less time to get to the opponent's goal.
9:24 Comment: Here's Lestienne.
9:29 Comment: Young, nice touch.
9:31 Comment: Matta.
9:33 Comment: Young has got the pace to get there and find a half-decent cross as well.
9:37 Comment: Well, more than half-decent, Arias had to put it behind.
9:42 Comment: He does that so well, Ashley Young, he hits balls early,
9:45 Comment: he's not blessed with unbelievable pace,
9:47 Comment: but you know when he gets the ball he's going to shift it out of his feet,
9:50 Comment: or whenever he gets the opportunity he's going to whip it in,
9:52 Comment: and either foot he can cross a decent ball.
9:55 Comment: That was a lovely ball.
9:57 Comment: Maybe if the likes of Martial and Depay had known him better
10:1 Comment: they would have been on the end of that.
10:5 Comment: Well, that chemistry's going to grow, you would think.
10:11 Comment: Manchester United without really setting pulses,
10:14 Comment: racing I think it's fair to say,
10:16 Comment: have moved into second place in the Premier League.
10:19 Comment: With respect for distance behind City, it should be added.
10:22 Comment: Guardado, again hustled out of it.
10:25 Comment: Herrera wide, here's Young, and he's over here, that one.
10:29 Comment: But they're definitely on Guardado's case.
10:32 Comment: United.
10:34 Comment: Yeah, and when you've got the three players almost in that central area,
10:37 Comment: obviously Schweinsteiger, Herrera,
10:39 Comment: but then you've got Mata just in the No. 10 role.
10:42 Comment: And you can afford to press that sitter.
10:49 Comment: Trapper.
10:51 Comment: And the Colombian international, Arias.
10:55 Comment: Trapper to pick it up again.
10:59 Comment: Now seeing offside flag against the Dutch international winger.
11:8 Comment: Yeah, he had made his run.
11:11 Comment: And then he was almost stood in an offside position,
11:13 Comment: didn't try to get back onside too quickly, as you see.
11:16 Comment: Pretty simple one.
11:28 Comment: Also in this group and meeting tonight, Wolfsburg,
11:31 Comment: who were runners-up in Germany last season,
11:34 Comment: that's why they're in CSKA Moscow.
11:39 Comment: I think Manchester United would go through,
11:41 Comment: but I think last season taught us with the English clubs,
11:43 Comment: nothing can be taken for granted.
11:45 Comment: Damiens up and under, hoping that Memphis gets under that,
11:49 Comment: but Bruma watched it well.
11:52 Comment: Schweinsteiger to pick it up.
11:56 Comment: If they can keep him fit and firing this season,
12:0 Comment: he might be vitally important in this Champions League campaign
12:3 Comment: with all his experience.
12:12 Comment: Mata.
12:17 Comment: Young and Damien working something down the right-hand side.
12:21 Comment: He'll be a Manchester United corner.
12:28 Comment: United's only defeat so far this season at Swansea,
12:32 Comment: where they didn't play well.
12:43 Comment: Memphis with the corner, which was a bit of a mishit in truth.
12:47 Comment: Top scorer in Holland last season, Memphis.
13:18 Comment: And they had a penalty at the weekend against Liverpool,
13:23 Comment: and revealed afterwards it was the first competitive penalty
13:27 Comment: he'd ever taken in his career.
13:30 Comment: He was out the team injured and one Mata was off the pitch,
13:33 Comment: so somebody had to do it.
13:35 Comment: Did it pretty well as well.
13:37 Comment: Here's Mata.
13:48 Comment: This is the possession football that Louis van Gaal
13:52 Comment: likes Manchester United to play.
13:59 Comment: The question is whether they can do it with the verve and zest
14:3 Comment: that some of the United critics have been calling for.
14:11 Comment: Luke Shaw, with a wonderful run through!
14:14 Comment: That was terrific from Shaw.
14:17 Comment: The burst of acceleration nearly took him all the way.
14:21 Comment: I just hope he's not badly injured here, Ian.
14:24 Comment: It was a fantastic run, pace, power,
14:27 Comment: all the things you associate with Luke Shaw.
14:29 Comment: He likes bombing forward, it's a last-ditch challenge.
14:33 Comment: He put his hand up straight away, and that's normally a bad sign.
14:36 Comment: He's obviously been plagued with injuries in his career at Manchester United so far,
14:40 Comment: but he's a good run of games this season.
14:42 Comment: That doesn't look good, does it?
14:44 Comment: Straight away, they are making the sign to the bench.
14:50 Comment: And the stretcher is going to come on.
14:52 Comment: Well, that is most unfortunate.
14:55 Comment: Luke Shaw, who'd been in absolutely wonderful form this season,
14:58 Comment: played every minute, and then that.
15:1 Comment: Oh, it's a shocker in.
15:3 Comment: It's a shocker.
15:7 Comment: It's a bad one, you can see straight away.
15:10 Comment: Yeah.
15:12 Comment: He was his right ankle got caught.
15:15 Comment: It's one of those that you see once and you don't want to see again.
15:19 Comment: It's a long-termer.
15:24 Comment: Oh, dear.
15:25 Comment: And that's of course not only very bad news for Luke Shaw and Manchester United,
15:31 Comment: but of course for England as well.
15:34 Comment: With the European Championships in mind.
15:37 Comment: The challenge has gone unpenalised.
15:41 Comment: Maybe we'll get another chance to look at that.
15:47 Comment: That's always a sickener out there, of course.
15:49 Comment: It's Neil Hoff, the United physio,
15:52 Comment: and Steve McAnally, the club doctor.
15:58 Comment: Well, he's in fantastic hands, I can vouch for that.
16:1 Comment: The referee's given a corner here,
16:3 Comment: so he obviously thinks it was a touch of the ball.
16:7 Comment: It's one of those where you need to see a replay to see if there was any foul play in there,
16:11 Comment: but you don't want to see the replay because it was such a horrific injury.
16:16 Comment: It really is horrible and sickening.
16:20 Comment: And all you can do is wish Luke Shaw the speediest of recoveries.
16:25 Comment: I was going to say, Michael, really, the issue of the challenge,
16:29 Comment: or whether it was a penalty or not, is almost academic, it seems, in the circumstances.
16:35 Comment: Yeah, you feel so sorry for him.
16:38 Comment: He's had his injury problems since he's been at Manchester United,
16:41 Comment: and this season he's been looking sensational.
16:45 Comment: Marcos Rojo to make his first appearance of the season.
16:50 Comment: Now there's a lot of concern from not only the Manchester United players,
16:53 Comment: but all the players on the pitch.
17:5 Comment: I think it's a bit of a shame that he's not playing.
17:8 Comment: I think he's a bit of a disappointment.
17:16 Comment: He's a disappointment.
17:46 Comment: A lot of the time in situations as a football player you'll see a challenge coming in,
17:50 Comment: and you're almost weighing up the risks.
17:52 Comment: Sometimes you'll ride the challenge, you'll jump over it,
17:55 Comment: you'll see that someone's going to get the ball,
17:57 Comment: but when you're about eight, nine yards out and you've gone on that run,
18:0 Comment: you see a goal at the end of it, you plant your leg, and that's what it was.
18:4 Comment: He planted his right leg to shoot with his left,
18:7 Comment: and the challenge came in while his right leg was planted,
18:10 Comment: and, well, it's, you know...
18:13 Comment: He's snapped his leg in half, basically, it's just a gruesome thing to see.
18:24 Comment: He just won his fifth and sixth caps for England,
18:27 Comment: and I remember Rio Ferdinand saying to us,
18:29 Comment: he can be England's left-back for the next ten years if he wants to be.
18:33 Comment: Yeah, everyone within the game thinks he's the real deal,
18:36 Comment: you speak to all the lads at United, they're all full of praise,
18:39 Comment: we've seen how good he is in the past, you don't get bought for lots of money
18:43 Comment: like he has without showing something,
18:45 Comment: and then at the start of this season he's been absolutely brilliant for Manchester United,
18:48 Comment: it's such a big blow to both club and country, and more importantly to him.
19:0 Comment: It always leaves a little bit of an atmosphere, doesn't it,
19:3 Comment: when the game resumes.
19:6 Comment: I've been around, unfortunately, for a few of these,
19:9 Comment: like the Aaron Ramsey one and the Eduardo one, both for Arsenal,
19:14 Comment: which you definitely didn't want to see again.
19:17 Comment: It's almost like the players don't want to make a tackle sometimes for five or ten minutes afterwards.
19:22 Comment: Yeah, especially when I played in a game for Liverpool when there were two broken legs in one game.
19:28 Comment: And it really is shocking, it takes you back for a good few five or ten minutes
19:34 Comment: while you think of your mate and how bad he is.
19:37 Comment: Obviously you'll track on with the game, but it's not easy.
19:42 Comment: Watching on, there's Ruud van Nistelrooy in the middle,
19:45 Comment: of course a star for both of these clubs, PSV Eindhoven and Manchester United.
19:52 Comment: Chatted to him a lot at the World Cup during the summer, and he's a lovely guy.
20:4 Comment: The stoppage has been for about six minutes so far, but frankly, the referee will just, of course,
20:10 Comment: let this go on for as long as it takes to make sure it's looked after in the best possible way.
20:20 Comment: But I'm afraid to say that is a very, very serious injury, as you said, Michael.
20:25 Comment: It is, you just hope that it's almost halfway up between the knee and the ankle
20:31 Comment: when you start fracturing, breaking your leg around your ankle area.
20:36 Comment: You're dealing with a joint there, it's almost mid-range between the knee and ankle.
20:42 Comment: I'm presuming, I'm guessing, that it's a bit of a problem.
20:47 Comment: It's a bit of a problem, but it's a bit of a problem.
20:53 Comment: I'm presuming, I'm guessing, that it's a bit of a problem.
20:56 Comment: It's a bit of a problem.
20:59 Comment: It looked like they both fractured immediately, so it'll be a rod down there, I suppose,
21:5 Comment: pins in it, and it'll be, as things go, a reasonably straightforward rehab,
21:10 Comment: but you're out for obviously many, many months.
21:14 Comment: I just hope there's no other complications in there,
21:17 Comment: but you'd think they'd be on the operating table in the coming day or so,

21:33 Comment: some 15 minutes into his Champions League debut.

22:35 Comment: for Luke Shaw,

summary:
In a thrilling encounter between PSV Eindhoven and Manchester United in the Champions League, the Dutch side emerged victorious in a tightly fought contest at Philips Stadion in Eindhoven, securing a 2-1 victory. As both teams took to the pitch, expectations were high for an engaging clash, and the game delivered in every aspect - drama, excitement, goals, and unfortunately, a significant injury.

The match kicked off amidst a cacophony of sound from the passionate Estadio PSV fans. Within the first few minutes, Manchester United looked confident, with their return to the Champions League under the watchful eyes of European football enthusiasts around the globe. PSV, on the other hand, started energetically, eager to make their mark. Early indications showed PSV keen to utilize Luke de Jong, who had been prolific in the Dutch league with five goals already in as many games.

Daley Blint and Chris Smalling were alert at the back, cutting off early threats from PSV. Just as the game was finding its rhythm, Manchester United suffered a major blow when Luke Shaw made a marauding run, only to be brought down by a horrific challenge. Shaw went down clutching his leg, prompting immediate concern. The defender, who had been in excellent form this season, was stretchered off around the 15th minute mark. It was a sad sight seeing Shaw leave the field in what was clearly a severe injury.

As Marcos Rojo made his way onto the pitch to replace Shaw, the mood on the pitch slightly somber, Manchester United tried to regain their focus. Schweinsteiger, alongside Ander Herrera and Juan Mata, aimed to control the midfield. Meanwhile, Memphis Depay, making his return to his former club, received quite a warm reception from the fans, as they showed their appreciation for his performances last season that led PSV to the title.

Memphis soon repaid United fans with a moment of brilliance. In the 41st minute, he picked up a well-placed pass from Blint, danced through the PSV defense with exquisite footwork, and slotted the ball coolly through the legs of Zoet. The Manchester United winger's goal lit up the encounter and silenced the partisan home crowd momentarily. His celebration, despite the friendly ties to PSV, was a clear indication of his commitment to his new team.

Just when it appeared that Manchester United would go into the break with a lead, PSV responded. Maxime Lestienne's corner found Hector Morenoâs head in first-half stoppage time, and the ball deflected off Daley Blind into the net. The goal brought jubilant reactions from the PSV supporters, who roared back into life. The first half thus concluded with the scores tied at 1-1, a reflection of the competitive nature of the game.

As the second half commenced, a change in tactics was noted from Manchester United. Surprisingly, Ashley Young and Memphis Depay switched flanks, seemingly aimed at offering a different attacking approach. However, the early minutes of the second half saw Manchester United dominate possession without creating clear chances. Rojo and Smalling were solid at the back, hoping to stifle any PSV counter-attacks.

Manchester Unitedâs threat grew through Juan Mata and Memphis Depay, who combined well with Anthony Martial. However, against the run of play, in the 57th minute, PSV struck again. Guardado threaded a perfect ball to Lestienne, who delivered a pinpoint cross, finding Luciano Narsingh. The forward made no mistake with his header, placing it past De Gea and sending the home crowd into delirium with PSV taking a 2-1 lead.

From this point, the game became a series of relentless Manchester United pressures and steadfast PSV defensive resilience. Schweinsteiger orchestrated the midfield with his usual mix of vision and determination, and memorable runs from Martial caused PSV defenders to scramble. Young and Memphis continued to press from the wings but often found clearances from the ever-present Jeffrey Bruma, who stood like a colossus in defense.

Marouane Fellaini was introduced to add aerial dominance, and his presence brought an immediate change. Crosses began to target the Belgian, but PSV's defense held firm. Even when Mata found himself with a golden chance, his attempted strike was thwarted by quick PSV reactions. Fellaini managed to create some opportunities, yet the breakthrough evaded Manchester United.

As time ticked down, Manchester Unitedâs frustrations grew. An increasing urgency in their play led to turnovers and loose balls, which PSV capitalized on to relieve pressures intermittently. Despite dominating the possession statistics, Manchester United found clear-cut opportunities hard to come by, and the resolute PSV defense stood their ground.

Borussia Dortmund's young talent, JÃ¼rgen Locardia, came on for PSV alongside the experienced Stijn Schaars to inject fresh legs and preserve their slender lead. Meanwhile, Valencia replaced a tiring Young for United, and Memphis moved back to the left wing. However, even these changes were insufficient to alter the game's outcome.

As the match reached its conclusion, Manchester United continued to throw everything forward. Mata had another glaring opportunity that he failed to capitalize on, summing up a frustrating night for Unitedâs attack. Meanwhile, PSV remained disciplined, with Burnett and Guardado particularly crucial in breaking up opposition play.

The final whistle blew after several tense minutes of added time, confirming PSV's surprising yet hard-earned victory. Manchester United had paid the price for not converting possession into goals and for defensive lapses at crucial moments. For Louis van Gaal and his squad, this served as an immediate reminder that the Champions League demands precision and lethality in both penalty areas.

In reflecting on the game, one couldnât help but think about the unfortunate injury to Luke Shaw, which fundamentally shifted the dynamic of the match early. Van Gaal's complicated record at the Philips Stadion continued, and his post-match comments underscored a night of mixed emotions and analysis.

PSV Eindhovenâs victory was not just valuable in points but symbolic in showing their capability to hang with Europeâs elite on their return to the grand stage after some years. Their victory exemplified precision, grit, and excellent teamwork, qualities that won them this engaging encounter in the southern part of the Netherlands.
